document.docAuthor: Rahayu, Dwi Listyo & Ng, Peter K. L.
document.docTitle: Hexaplax aurantium Rahayu & Ng 2014, new species
document.masterDocTitle: New genera and new species of Hexapodidae (Crustacea, Brachyura) from the Indo-West Pacific and east Atlantic

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: New genera and new species of Hexapodidae (Crustacea, Brachyura) from the Indo-West Pacific and east Atlantic

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Hexaplax megalops
–
Tesch, 1918: 242
. (not
Hexaplax megalops Doflein, 1904
)

subSubSection.paragraph:

460–466 m
, Papua New Guinea , coll. BIOPAPUA Expedition,
2 October 2010
.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 62.
Hexaplax megalops Doflein, 1904
. A–D, male (18.7 × 12.1 mm) (MNHN-IU-2011-2251); E, female (17.7 × 12.2 mm) (MNHN- IU-2011-2251). A, left third maxilliped; B, male abdomen and telson; C, D, G1; E, female abdomen and telson. Scale bars = 1.0 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Colour. In life, the carapace is cream-mottled with orange margin, the eye is cream with orange longitudinal stripes on the lateral and mesial margins, and an orange spot under the cornea. T cheliped is white with an orange stripe on the articulation of the dactylus and palm, and distal margins of the carpus and merus of P2−P4 are orangish-white ( Fig. 2F ).

Etymology. From the Latin noun
aurantium
for citrus; alluding to the orange colour of the species in life.

Remarks. See remarks for
H. megalops
s. str. for differences with congeners.

Tesch (1918) recorded several specimens of “
Hexaplax megalops
” from Saleyer Island (southern Sulawesi) and north of Bali. On the basis of the adult measurements provided by Tesch (1918: 243) , the carapace width to length ratios of these specimens ranged from 1.34 to 1.43, indicating they probably belong to
H. aurantium
, new species .
Hexaplax megalops
, which also occurs in New Guinea waters and may be present in Sulawesi and Bali, has a proportionately broader carapace, with a width to length ratio of 1.5.

Type locality.
Madang , Papua New Guinea
.

Distribution. Papua New Guinea . Deep water,
280− 655 m
.
